content.description: Surprisingly fun climbing is to be had on this route as you work the wide slot getting good gear in smaller cracks on the side of the chimney. The climbing feels secure but not restrictive, and some stemming as well as heel-to-toeing come into play along the route. Descend by walking east (climber's left) and rapping off anchors atop Earth Daze or by heading south and downclimbing a series of ledges on the west side of Dinosaur Rock.
content.location:
The obvious chimney/break between

Cinder

and

Velociraptor

.

climbs.name: Velociraptor
climbs.fa: Brad Singer, John Cardmon & Bob Cable, July 1998

content.description:
This is the right-most climb on the north face and is located just right of an obvious wide chimney/break in the wall (

Wooly Mammoth

).

Boulder up a short thin crack and then climb past several ledges to a wide hand/fist crack before finishing up a gritty finger/thin hand crack in vertical rock. Descend by walking east (climber's left) and rapping off anchors atop Earth Daze or by heading south and downclimbing a series of ledges on the west side of Dinosaur Rock.

Decent climbing on this but the rock is awfully sharp - best to tape unless you want to feed the Velociraptor.

This is the left most bolted route on the North face.

Scramble up to the large ledge to start.   Move of the ledge to clip the first bolt.   After clipping the bolt make a tricky sequence of moves to reach up right to the good slanting ledge.   Mantle onto the ledge and move directly up.

Move easily up to the 3rd bolt where the second crux starts.

After clipping the the 4th bolt make technical balance moves up to a far off flake on the right.   From the flake continue with interest to the anchors.

Starts with a short vertical section to a sloping ledge then up past the prominent horizontal crack to an interesting section of face with edges, a hueco and helpful undercling with the crux coming at the very end right before the anchors.

Taller climbers may find it easier than advertised if able to clip the anchors from a lower position.
content.location:
Between

Earth Daze

and

Cinder

on the north side of the rock.

climbs.name: Earth Daze
climbs.fa: (TR) Mike Rigney et al, FL: Brad Singer, September 1999

content.description:
Located slightly right of center on the north face of Lower Dinosaur Rock. Look for the smoothest, nicest-looking section of wall with a horizontal crack at mid-height; this is the left of three bolted lines.

Slab climbing past two bolts leads to a horizontal (optional pro here) which bisects the face at mid-height. Above the angle steepens and interesting face moves culminate with the crux right before the anchors.

* The first ascent was done on

Earth Day

, hence the name.

Start by groveling up the wide crack to the right of the blunt rounded arete.   After the awkward start, move left onto the arete proper.   Continue with delicate technical moves up the from of the arete until the crux sequence up onto the large ledge to the left is encountered.

Once established on the ledge move straight up to the steeping face.   What follows is straightforward, albeit enjoyable, face climbing on small positive flakes.

As you near the top move right to gain a large but very fragile flake.   Gingerly move up this flake until possible to make a move to the anchors.
content.location:
Right side of the face that lies right of center.   This climbs the face immediately left of

Wooly Mammoth

climbs.name: Buzz Off
climbs.fa: Bob Cable, Brad Singer & John Cardmon, July 1998

content.description: Climb the grainy crack just to the left of the tree. It becomes an off-width grovelfest near the top.
content.protection: Gear to 5 inches, plus long sleeves and pants.
content.location:
The wide crack just to the right of

Sprockets

(just left of the tree).

climbs.name: Bloody Ankles
climbs.fa: John Cardmon, Brad Singer & Bob Cable, July 1998

content.description:
Climb the broken blocks to get up to the crack.   Follow the crack or about 15' then step rightwards into the rounded off-width.

Climb the off-width, using the occasional face hold on the right.

The top is particularly interesting.
content.protection:
Trad rack - large cams for the top crack.

Alternatively you can TR this from the anchors on

Sprockets

.
